questions.text: A 10-year-old child is got to the OPD with complaints of poor appetite and failure to thrive. Upon further clinical examination, loss of skin turgor, and dry mucous membranes are noted. What is the glucose content of the rehydration solution used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 125 mmol/L

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations indicate dehydration in a malnourished child requiring ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition).

  • The patient presents with classic signs of dehydration including poor appetite, failure to thrive, loss of skin turgor, and dry mucous membranes.
  • ReSoMal is specifically formulated for malnourished children with a precise glucose concentration of 125 mmol/L.
  • This solution differs from standard oral rehydration solutions by having lower sodium and higher potassium content to address the specific needs of malnourished children.
  • The osmolality of approximately 300 mOsm/L helps maintain appropriate fluid balance during rehydration.

Composition of Rehydration Solutions

Component

Resomal (300 mOsm/L)

Standard ORS (311 mOsm/L)

Reduced Osmolarity ORS (245 mOsm/L)

Sodium

45 mmol/L

90 mmol/L

75 mmol/L

Potassium

40 mmol/L

20 mmol/L

20 mmol/L

Chloride

70 mmol/L

80 mmol/L

65 mmol/L

Citrate

7 mmol/L

10 mmol/L

10 mmol/L

Glucose

125 mmol/L

111 mmol/L

75 mmol/L

Zinc

40 μmol/L

-

-

Copper

70 μmol/L

-

-

Magnesium

3 mmol/L

-

-

Total Osmolarity

300 mOsm/L

311 mOsm/L

245 mOsm/L

 

100 mmol/L (Option A): This glucose concentration is too low for effective rehydration in malnourished children. A lower glucose concentration would not provide adequate carbohydrate substrate for sodium-glucose cotransport in the intestine.

150 mmol/L (Option C): This concentration exceeds the recommended glucose content for ReSoMal. Higher glucose concentrations can lead to osmotic diarrhea and worsen dehydration.

200 mmol/L (Option D): This concentration is significantly higher than the standard ReSoMal formulation. Such high glucose concentrations can cause osmotic fluid shifts and potentially worsen the child's condition.

questions.text: Which of the following cataracts is seen in blunt trauma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rosette cataract

Explanation: Rosette-shaped cataract: it is a cortical cataract that starts from the posterior cortex is seen in blunt trauma.

Traumatic cataract:

  • A traumatic cataract is an acquired cataract resulting from ocular trauma, such as penetrating or blunt injuries.
  • It forms due to degeneration in previously normal lens fibers.
  • Morphological Forms
    • Subepithelial Opacities: Most common presentation.
    • Rosette Cataracts
      • Early Rosette: Feathery opacities along posterior cortex suture lines; typical of concussion cataracts. (Option C)
      • Late Rosette: Develops 1-2 years post-injury, with shorter, compact sutural extensions.
      • Diffuse Concussion Cataract: Common presentation of total cataract following blunt trauma, which may accelerate senile cataract development.
  • Subepithelial Opacities (Option A) are common but do not typically present with feathery opacities along suture lines.
  • Diffuse Concussion Cataract (Option B) involves widespread lens opacity, not localized feathery patterns..

Toxic cataract (Option B) causes posterior subcapsular cataract. It can be caused by steroids, phenothiazines, mong acting miotics, amiodarone, busulfan, gold, chloroquine

Metabolic cataract (Option C):

  • Due to Diabetes mellitus
  • It can occur due to 2 enzyme deficiencies
    • Galactokinase - causes lamellar cataract
    • GPUT - causes oil drop cataract

Nuclear cataract (Option D):

  • It is due to nuclear sclerosis
  • Sclerosis can be caused due to denaturation of the protein resulting in an increase in insoluble protein and a decrease in soluble protein, and deposition of pigments such as melanin and urochrome.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a lesion on his arm after working with cattle on his farm. Gram staining of a sample from the lesion reveals gram-positive rods with square ends and central spores. What is the most likely organism causing this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bacillus anthracis

Explanation:

The description of gram-positive rods with square ends and central spores is a hallmark of Bacillus anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax. Anthrax is a zoonotic infection that is typically contracted by handling infected animals or animal products, which is consistent with the farmer’s exposure to cattle. The cutaneous form of anthrax presents with a painless ulcer that forms a characteristic black eschar, which is highly suggestive of Bacillus anthracis infection.

  • The presentation of a black necrotic lesion (eschar) surrounded by swelling and secondary vesicles is characteristic of cutaneous anthrax, which occurs when Bacillus anthracis spores enter through damaged skin. MO
  • Commonly seen in dock workers carrying hides and skins on their bare backs. Also known as Hide-Porter’s disease.

 

Name

Microscopy

Features

Bacillus Anthracis

Bacillus anthracis appears as large (3-10 µm x 1-1.6 µm), rectangular, rod-shaped bacteria (“box-car appearance”), often arranged in chains. It is Gram-positive.

It is

 

Blood Culture Morphology:

Characteristic

Description

Blood Agar
  • Large (2 to 5 mm), grey, flat, non-hemolytic colonies with irregular margins- giving a frosted glass appearance.
  • Tenacious consistency firmly adheres to agar.
  • "Medusa head" appearance under microscope.

Agar with Penicillin
  • Susceptible to penicillin.
  • Grows large, spherical cells in 3-6 hours on media with 0.05-0.50 units of penicillin/ml.
  • Forms "string of pearls" chains.

Gelatin Liquefaction
  • Obligate aerobe.
  • More growth and energy production at the surface.
  • Liquefaction starts from the top, resembling an "inverted fir tree".

PLET Medium

 

 
  • Contains polymyxin, lysozyme, EDTA, and thallous acetate in heart infusion agar (PLET)
  • Selective for isolating B. anthracis from samples with other spore-forming bacilli.

Serology

 

 

 
  • Ascoli's Thermoprecipitin Test: Detects anthrax antigens in tissue extracts.
  • DFA: Detects antibodies against B. anthracis; confirms presence via cell wall polysaccharide and capsule antigens.

Laboratory Safety Note
  • High risk of infection from spores.
  • Caution is advised when handling B.anthracis isolates.

 

Brucella abortus (Option A): This bacterium causes brucellosis, another zoonotic disease that can be transmitted by cattle. However, Brucella does not produce spores and does not have the characteristic gram-positive rods with square ends.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option B): This gram-negative bacterium is more often associated with infections in immunocompromised patients, particularly in burn wounds or respiratory infections, but it does not match the description of gram-positive rods with spores.

Bacillus cereus (Option D): While Bacillus cereus is also a spore-forming gram-positive rod, it is typically associated with food poisoning or gastrointestinal issues, not cutaneous lesions with the described appearance.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting, binge drinking, and heavy meals presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe left-sided chest pain radiating to the left shoulder. Pneumoperitoneum is noted on X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Esophageal perforation

Explanation:

  • Esophageal perforation, particularly Boerhaave’s syndrome, is the most likely diagnosis. The patient’s history of multiple episodes of vomiting, binge drinking, and heavy meals, combined with sudden, severe chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, strongly suggests a rupture of the esophagus. (Boerhaave’s syndrome)
  • Boerhaave's syndrome is characterized by spontaneous esophageal perforation due to forceful vomiting. Key features include severe chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema.

Esophageal perforation

Definition

A breach in the esophageal wall leads to leakage and increased morbidity and mortality

Causes

Iatrogenic injury, spontaneous (Boerhaave's syndrome), foreign bodies, corrosive substances, eosinophilic esophagitis, esophageal cancer

Symptoms
  • Varies by cause and location:
  • Iatrogenic (recent instrumentation)
  • Boerhaave's (vomiting, chest pain, emphysema)
  • Cervical (neck pain, etc.)

Diagnosis

Imaging: Chest X-ray, contrast swallow studies, CT scan

Management
  • Seal perforation, ensure drainage, supportive measures (nutrition, cardiorespiratory support, sepsis control)
  • Conservative Management: Suitable for stable patients: antibiotics, nil by mouth, observation
  • Endoscopic Interventions: Visualization, retrieval, sealing with clips/stents, nasogastric tube placement
  • Surgical Intervention: Required for significant sepsis, large perforations, pleural involvement, delayed presentation
  • Surgical Options: Primary repair, controlled fistula creation, esophageal diversion, esophagectomy (rare)

Incorrect Options:

Mediastinal air leak (Option A) can be a result of various causes, including trauma or infections, but the patient’s history and symptoms make esophageal perforation more likely.

Pneumoperitoneum (Option C) refers to air in the peritoneal cavity, often due to a perforated abdominal viscus, such as a perforated ulcer. However, the patient's presentation are more consistent with esophageal perforation.

Peptic ulcer (Option D) can cause abdominal pain and potentially lead to perforation, but it typically does not cause chest pain radiating to the shoulder or the presence of pneumoperitoneum as seen in this case.

questions.text: A farmer has a lesion on the shoulder. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the histopathological image of the lesion given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) SCC

Explanation:

  • The histopathological image showing keratin pearls on histopathology is suggestive of Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC).
  • It is a malignant tumour originating from epidermal keratinocytes.
  • It is the second most common skin tumour after basal cell carcinoma (BCC).
  • SCC is notably the most common skin tumour in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Predisposing factors include UV exposure, immunosuppression, and conditions like xeroderma pigmentosum, albinism, LP, and DLE, which can rarely progress into SCC.
  • Clinical features:
    • It typically exhibits a lower rate of local, regional, and distant spread compared to other skin malignancies.
    • Associated with immunocompromised states such as HIV infection and renal transplant recipients.
    • It presents as papules, nodules, or plaques with induration and signs of photodamage like crusting and scaling.
  • Histopathological examination reveals characteristic keratin pearls.
  • Treatment:
    • Primary treatment involves wide surgical excision with margins.
    • Advanced cases may require radiation or chemotherapy.

 

BCC (Basal Cell Carcinoma) (Option B) is the most common type of skin cancer, originating from the basal cells in the epidermis. It is typically slow-growing, often appearing as a painless, pearly nodule with telangiectasias on sun-exposed areas like the face. Histologically, BCC is characterised by nests of basaloid cells with a palisading pattern at the periphery, fibrotic stroma, and clefting between the tumour and surrounding tissue.

 

Molluscum contagiosum (Option C) is a viral skin infection causing small, flesh-coloured lesions with central umbilication, often in children and immunocompromised individuals. Histologically, it shows epidermal hyperplasia, ballooning keratinocytes, and Henderson-Patterson (HP) bodies in cup-shaped spaces.

 

Verrucous carcinoma (Option D) is a rare, low-grade squamous cell carcinoma often found in areas with chronic irritation (e.g., oral cavity, genitals). It presents as a slow-growing, wart-like lesion and is associated with HPV infection. Histopathologically, it shows exophytic growth, thick keratinisation, well-differentiated squamous cells, and pushing borders with minimal atypia.

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Basal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

The histopathological image of the skin biopsy reveals nests of basaloid cells with peripheral palisading and a distinctive stromal retraction artefact, characteristic of Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC), also known as Rodent Ulcer.

  • It is the most common type of skin cancer and is typically seen in sun-exposed areas of the skin.
  • It is a slow-growing, locally invasive tumour, and it rarely metastasises.
  • Origin: Arises from pluripotent cells within the basal layer of the epidermis or follicular structures.
  • Pathogenesis:

  • Site: Face, Around eyes, Nose
  • Clinical Features
    • It presents initially small, scaly plaque.
    • They present as pearly papules containing dilated blood vessels (telangiectasias)
    • They may ulcerate locally and invade the underlying bone or facial sinuses (rodent ulcers).
    • Slow progressive course of peripheral extension.
  • Histologically: The tumour cells are basophilic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei (basaloid cells) arranged in clusters with a palisading pattern. The stroma sometimes retracts from the malignant cells.
  • Treatment
    • Medical: Imiquimod, 5-FU,Intralesional interferon α-2b
    • Hedgehog pathway inhibitors:(Vismodegib)
    • Surgical: Mohs micrographic surgery, Done in recurrent BCCs.

 

Squamous cell Carcinoma (Option B) typically exhibits keratin pearls and intercellular bridges, features not present in the image provided. Additionally, the cells are generally larger and have more abundant cytoplasm, unlike the smaller basaloid cells seen in BCC.

 

Adenocarcinoma (Option C) arises from glandular epithelium and shows glandular structures or mucin production.

 

Malignant Melanoma (Option D) is characterised by atypical melanocytes, which can be seen in various configurations, such as nests or single cells within the epidermis and dermis. These cells often contain melanin pigment.

questions.text: Acute liver failure is a clinical feature of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Amanita Phalloides poisoning

Explanation:

  • Amanita poisoning causes acute liver failure. It is a wild mushroom known as the death cap mushroom. Amanita poisoning presents with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, enlarged and tender liver, jaundice, oliguria , mental confusion, convulsions and coma

 

Early mushroom poisoning

Late mushroom poisoning

Hallucinogenic mushroom poisoning

Species

Inocybe

Amanita phalloides

Amanita muscaria

Toxin

Muscarine

Amatoxin (Option A)

Muscimol

Symptoms

Cholinergic symptoms (DUMBBELLS)

Hepatotoxicity

Hallucinations, seizures

Treatment

Atropine

Thioctic acid

Silibinin

(hepatoprotective)

Supportive treatment

ATROPINE CONTRAINDICATED

OP poisoning (Option A) presents with pinpoint pupils and diaphoresis, liver failure is not seen

Belladonna poisoning (Option C) presents with tachycardia, hallucinations not liver failure

Morphine poisoning (Option D) presents with respiratory depression and pinpoint pupils, liver failure is not seen

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a bulky scrotal swelling. On evaluation, malignancy is suspected, and an orchidectomy is performed. The gross section of the testicular mass is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Seminoma

Explanation:

  • The gross section of the testicular mass shows a homogeneous, grey-white appearance without necrosis or hemorrhage, suggesting Seminoma, which is the most common testicular tumour.

Seminoma

Feature

Details

Tumor Type

Seminoma, the most common pure testicular germ cell tumour in men aged 25-45

Origin

Germinal epithelium of the seminiferous tubules

Clinical Features

Painless, firm swelling or mass in the testicle, typically unilateral. Accounts for 50% of all testicular germ cell tumors. 10% have secondary hydrocele, 5% have gynecomastia

Diagnostic Markers

AFP: Normal

hCG: Normal or mildly elevated

LDH: Elevated

Investigation

Ultrasound: Homogeneous, hypoechoic mass

Histology: Sheets of oval cells with clear cytoplasm, large nuclei with prominent acidophilic nucleoli

FNAC: Contraindicated due to risk of tumor cell seeding and lymph node metastasis

Treatment

Primary: High Inguinal Radical Orchidectomy

Adjuvant: Radiation therapy or chemotherapy for positive lymph nodes

Incorrect Options:

Teratoma (Option B), often contains multiple tissue types (e.g., cartilage, muscle, fat), and its gross appearance can be more heterogeneous, with cystic areas or areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.

Yolk sac tumor (Option C) (also known as an endodermal sinus tumor (Option BD)) is another common germ cell tumor, but it typically presents with areas of hemorrhage or necrosis, and is not homogenous with elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels.

questions.text: Where does the majority of water absorption occur within the renal tubules?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT)

Explanation:

  • The majority of water reabsorption within the renal tubules occurs in the Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT).
  • Approximately 65-70% of the filtered water is reabsorbed in the PCT.
  • This reabsorption process is critical for maintaining fluid balance and involves the active transport of sodium ions, which creates an osmotic gradient that drives water reabsorption.
  • The PCT also reabsorbs other essential substances such as glucose, amino acids, and electrolytes, contributing to the overall homeostasis of the body.

Tonicity in Nephron segments with relation to plasma:

Nephron Segment

Tonicity relative to Plasma

Filtration (Glomerulus)

Isotonic (Same as plasma osmolality)

Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT)

Isotonic

  • Absorption of solute is proportional to the reabsorption of water.

Thin Descending Limb

Hypertonic (Water reabsorption, no solute reabsorption)

  • Isotonic - - - - -> Hypertonic

Thick Ascending Limb

 

Isotonic (Solute reabsorption, no water reabsorption)

  • Hypertonic - - - - - > Isotonic

Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT)

Hypotonic

Collecting Duct (CD)

It depends upon the presence of ADH in the blood
  • With ADH, more reabsorption of water and Hypertonic.
  • Without ADH, water reabsorption is nil, which is more hypotonic.

Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT) (Option B): is responsible for fine-tuning the reabsorption of sodium and water, but it does not account for the majority of water reabsorption. It primarily adjusts the concentration of urine in response to hormonal signals.

Loop of Henle (LOH) (Option C): plays a significant role in establishing the medullary osmotic gradient, crucial for water reabsorption in the collecting duct, but does not absorb the majority of water.

Collecting Duct (Option D): While the collecting duct is responsible for the final adjustments in water reabsorption under the influence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), the majority of water absorption has already occurred by this point in the PCT.

questions.text: The hysterosalpingogram of a patient shows fluid-filled S-shaped structures on both sides. Choose the best answer correlating to this finding.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bilateral hydrosalpinx

Explanation:

  • The finding of fluid-filled S-shaped structures on both sides in a hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is characteristic of bilateral hydrosalpinx.

Hydrosalpinx:

  • Definition: Distention of fallopian tube with fluid
  • Appearance: Characteristic S-shaped or serpentine structure
  • HSG finding: Dilated, convoluted fallopian tubes
  • Distribution: Can be unilateral or bilateral

Hysterosalpingography

  • It is a radiographic imaging technique.

Indication:

  • Infertility evaluation
  • To assess the endocervical canal, the endometrial cavity, and the fallopian tube lumina and patency.

Procedure:

  • Radiopaque contrast material is injected through the cervical canal.
  • It is performed between cycle days 5 and 10.

Normal findings:

  • The spill of contrast from the tubes into the peritoneal cavity suggests patency of the fallopian tubes.
  • The endometrial cavity is usually triangular and has a smooth contour.

Contraindications:

  • Acute pelvic infection
  • Active uterine bleeding
  • Pregnancy
  • Iodine allergy

 

Normal HSG (Option A): In a normal HSG, fallopian tubes appear as thin, linear structures with free spillage of contrast into the peritoneal cavity. The S-shaped dilated appearance is not seen in normal tubes. The radiograph below shows normal HSG.

Bilateral cornual block (Option B): Cornual block shows complete obstruction at the proximal fallopian tubes with no filling of the tubes beyond the cornual region. This would not show S-shaped fluid-filled structures.

Extravasation into venous system (Option C): Venous extravasation appears as irregular, thin channels with rapid dissipation of contrast material. It does not present as bilateral S-shaped structures and is typically seen as a complication during HSG.

questions.text: A patient presents with a foul smell from the nose, anosmia, and nasal obstruction. The following is noted during examination. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Atrophic rhinitis

Explanation:

  • The image shows crusting and a wide roomy nasal cavity
  • The patient has anosmia beacuse the his olfactory fibres are atrophic-merciful anosmia
  • The people around the patient complain of foul smell where the patient is unaware of this. Hence called as merciful anosmia.
  • All these are features of atrophic rhinitis:
    • Primarily affects females, starts around puberty
    • Foul-smelling nasal discharge; patients are usually unaware of it themselves and have anosmia (merciful anosmia).
    • Paradoxical nasal obstruction despite enlarged nasal chambers.
    • Epistaxis from crust removal.
    • Pale nasal mucosa, atrophied turbinates, potential septal perforation, nasal vestibule dermatitis, saddle nose deformity.
    • Possible extension to pharynx and larynx leading to atrophic pharyngitis and laryngitis.
    • Eustachian tube obstruction and middle ear effusion cause hearing impairment.

 

Incorrect Options:

Rhinitis sicca (Option B):

  • Exposure to dry/hot climates (typically seen in people working in bakeries).
  • The crusting is limited to only anterior ⅓ of the nose and there is no associated anosmia in this case.

 

Rhinitis medicamentosa (Option C):

  • This is due to abuse of alpha adrenergic agonist like xylometazoline which cause nasal obstruction and discharge

 

Allergic rhinitis (Option D):

  • There is serum IgE involved , which causes profuse nasal discharge but not crusting.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant female in her first trimester presents to the OPD for a regular antenatal checkup. During blood type screening, potential ABO incompatibility is discussed. The healthcare provider explains that certain antibody types are less concerning than others during pregnancy. ABO incompatibility does not occur due to which antibody in her case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D) IgM

Explanation:

The clinical scenario addresses maternal-fetal ABO incompatibility and antibody transfer across the placenta:

  • IgM antibodies cannot cross the placenta due to their large molecular size
  • Placental transfer is selective and depends on antibody structure.
  • Only IgG antibodies can effectively cross the placenta
  • ABO incompatibility occurs primarily through IgG-mediated hemolysis

 

IgA (Option A): While IgA antibodies are not known to cross the placenta, it is not the primary antibody class that's excluded from crossing the placenta.

IgG (Option B): IgG is the only antibody that is known to cross the placenta, making it the primary concern in blood type incompatibility.

IgD (Option C): IgD antibodies are not known to cross the placenta, it is not the primary antibody class that's excluded from crossing the placenta.

questions.text: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs can cause glucosuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Empagliflozin

Explanation:

  • Empagliflozin belongs to the class of SGLT-2 inhibitors that work by blocking sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 in the proximal convoluted tubules of the nephron. This mechanism prevents the reabsorption of glucose and sodium back into the bloodstream, leading to glucosuria.
  • The drug provides multiple benefits including reduced progression of chronic kidney disease, diuretic effects through sodium loss, and blood pressure reduction of 3-6 mmHg. However, these drugs are contraindicated in patients with eGFR <45 ml/min due to reduced efficacy and risk of urinary tract infections.

Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) Inhibitors

Examples
  • Canagliflozin
  • Dapagliflozin
  • Empagliflozin

Mechanism of Action

  • Blocks reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubule, promoting the excretion of sodium and glucose in urine

Indications
  • Reduce progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD)
  • Diuretic effect, leading to sodium loss
  • Reduces systolic blood pressure (SBP) by 3-6 mmHg
  • Cardiorenal advantage
  • CHF to decrease mortality with or without DM

Side Effects
  • Increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Glucosuria (leading to UTIs and vulvovaginal candidiasis)
  • Dehydration (orthostatic hypotension)
  • Weight loss

Contraindications
  • Not recommended if estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) < 45 ml/min
  • Use with caution in renal insufficiency (decreased efficacy with decreased GFR)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Glimepiride (Option A): This sulfonylurea medication works by stimulating insulin release from pancreatic beta cells, causing hypoglycemia and weight gain. It does not cause glucosuria as its mechanism of action is focused on increasing insulin secretion.

Exenatide (Option B): This GLP-1 receptor agonist binds to GLP-1 receptor in pancreatic beta-cells in turn increasing insulin secretion and suppressing glucagon secretion. Its actions include delayed gastric emptying, induces early satiety (weight loss) & stabilizes atherosclerotic plaque (reduction in cardiovascular mortality). Its mechanism does not involve renal glucose reabsorption thus does not cause glucosuria.

Acarbose (Option C): This alpha-glucosidase inhibitor works by controlling post-prandial glucose spikes through reduced carbohydrate absorption in the intestine. It may cause abdominal bloating and diarrhea but does not affect renal glucose handling or cause glucosuria.

questions.text: Iron absorption is decreased in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Tea

  • Tannin in tea interferes with iron absorption.

Sources rich in iron:

Two types: haem-iron and non-haem iron.

  • Haem iron

    • Haem iron is better absorbed than non-haem iron.

    • Found in liver, meat, poultry, and fish.

    • Promotes absorption of non-haem iron in plant foods eaten concurrently.

  • Non-Haem iron:

    • It is found in plant-based foods such as cereals, green leafy vegetables, legumes, nuts, oilseeds, jaggery, and dried fruits.

  • Additional Iron Sources: Cooking in iron vessels can significantly contribute to dietary iron in some areas.

  • Iron Content in Milk:

    • Low in all mammalian species.

    • Breast milk contains less than 0.2 mg/dL but has good bioavailability.

Bioavailability and Absorption Inhibitors:

  • Non-haem iron absorption is hindered by phytates, oxalates, carbonates, phosphates, and dietary fibre.

  • Foods like milk, eggs, and tea also inhibit iron absorption.

  • Indian vegetarian diets often contain high levels of these inhibitors (e.g., phytates in bran, phosphates in egg yolk, tannin in tea, and oxalates in vegetables).

Incorrect Options:

Amla (Option A): Vitamin C in Amla is the promoter of iron absorption

Sprouts (Option B): Sprouting promotes iron absorption.

Lemon (Option D): Vitamin C in Lemon is the promoter of iron absorption

questions.text: A group of people are travelling to the mountains, and a girl starts complaining of mountain sickness. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acetazolamide

Explanation:

  • The drug of choice for preventing and treating acute mountain sickness is acetazolamide.
  • It is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts on PCT and leads to Na+/HCO3- excretion in urine.
  • In Mountain sickness (acute mountain sickness or AMS), at high altitudes, lower oxygen levels lead to hyperventilation, which causes CO2 washout and respiratory alkalosis (alkaline blood suppresses CNS).
  • Symptoms include headache, nausea, dizziness, fatigue, and shortness of breath.
  • When Acetazolamide is taken, it produces metabolic acidosis and reduces hyperventilation.

Promethazine (Option A) is an antihistamine commonly used for motion sickness, nausea, and vertigo. While it can relieve nausea and dizziness associated with mountain sickness, it does not address the underlying acclimatisation issues that cause AMS.

Dimenhydrinate (Option C) is another antihistamine used for motion sickness and nausea. Like promethazine, it helps with symptoms but does not prevent or treat the root cause of mountain sickness.


Thiazide (Option D) diuretics are primarily used for managing hypertension and edema. They are not used for mountain sickness and have no role in altitude adaptation.

questions.text: A family died in a closed room that was full of smoke from a wood fire. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Cherry red hypostasis

Explanation:

In this scenario, a family died in a closed room full of smoke from a wood fire, which likely caused carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning. Cherry-red post-mortem staining is a hallmark sign of carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.

Postmortem Staining in Poisoning Cases

  • Postmortem staining (Livor mortis) is the skin discoloration after death due to blood settling in dependent areas.
  • The color of the staining can indicate certain types of poisoning:

Poison

Postmortem Staining Characteristics

Opium (Option C ruled out)

Purple or blackish staining

Carbon monoxide (Option A)

Cherry red discoloration (COHb > 30%)

Hydrogen sulfide

Greenish discoloration in tissues

Datura

Asphyxial signs (no specific color)

Organochlorine/Kerosene

Asphyxial signs (no specific color)

Phosphates, aniline, and nitrites (Option D ruled out)

Brown-colored pigmentation

 

Carbon Monoxide

Physical Appearance
  • Odourless, colorless, non-irritating gas, lighter than air

Sources of Poisoning
  • Incomplete combustion of almost of fuel (wood, charcoal, gas, kerosene)
  • Automobile exhaust
  • Fires: A common cause of accidental CO poisoning resulting in mass deaths - large building (hotel, theatre, block of flats, etc.) in flames
  • Paint remover (especially methylene chloride)
  • Tobacco smoke

Normal CO level in plasma
  • 1 to 5 %
  • 7 to 8 % in smokers

Mode of Action
  • 230 to 270 times greater affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen
  • Leftward shift of the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve
  • Reduced arterial oxygen content
  • Inactivating mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase - cellular respiration is interfered
  • CO-induced brain injuries are common in basal ganglia, cerebral white matter, hippocampus, and cerebellum.

Clinical Features
  • Depends on the concentration of CO in the blood
  • CO exposure during pregnancy is teratogenic

Diagnosis
  • Carboxyhemoglobin level (COHb) in blood
  • Arterial blood gases

Treatment
  • Oxygen (100%) through a tight-fitting mask or endotracheal tube, until COHb falls to 15 to 20%
  • Hyperbaric oxygen: Inhalation of oxygen at a pressure greater than 1 atmosphere absolute

Autopsy Findings
  • Cherry red (pink) color of skin, inner aspects of lips, nail beds, tongue, palms and soles
  • Cutaneous bullae (skin blisters) in the calves, buttocks, wrists, and knees
  • Cherry pink color of blood and tissues
  • Firmer white matter of the brain
  • Necrosis and cavitation of basal ganglia

Cyanosis (Option B) is not appreciated in CO poisoning.

questions.text: Which Leopold's maneuver is done to assess the lie of the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Leopold's 1

Explanation:

  • Leopold's maneuver 1 is specifically used to determine the fetal lie through abdominal palpation.

Key Features of Leopold's 1:

  • Purpose: Determines fetal lie and presentation
  • Technique: Palpation of fundus
  • Assessment: Identifies which fetal part occupies the fundus
  • Outcome: Determines longitudinal versus transverse lie

Maneuver

Hand Position

Purpose

Findings

First (Fundal Grip)

Both hands on fundus facing patient

Determines fetal presentation and position

Identifies fetal parts (head or buttocks)

Head: Hard, round

Breech: Soft, irregular

Second (Lateral Grip)

Hands placed on sides of abdomen

Locate fetal back and limbs

Back: Smooth surface

Limbs: Small knob-like parts

Third (Deep Pelvic)

Thumb and fingers grasp above symphysis pubis

Identify presenting part

Determines if head is engaged

Head: Hard, round

Breech: Soft, irregular

Fourth (Pelvic Grip)

Facing patient's feet, fingers pressed downward

Assess engagement

Confirms cephalic prominence

Engaged: Fixed part

Not engaged: Mobile part

questions.text: Anencephaly occurs due to the inability of the neural tube to close at which week of intrauterine life?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 4th week

Explanation:

Anencephaly is a severe neural tube defect that occurs at the 4th week of gestation due to failure of closure of the rostral neuropore

  • Results in absence of:
    • Scalp
    • Cranial bones
    • Meninges
  • Rudimentary brain tissue is exposed to the external environment which is incompatible with life.
  • Anencephaly is a severe neural tube defect characterized by the partial or complete absence of the brain and cranial vault, resulting from the failure of neural tube closure during early fetal development.
  • During labor, it may present with face presentation or shoulder dystocia.
  • Prenatal ultrasound shows the absence of the cranial vault, exposed brain tissue, and the "frog eye sign," characterised by a flattened head with prominent, bulging orbits.

3rd week (Option A): At this stage, neurulation has just begun, and the neural tube formation is still in its early phases. The critical closure of the rostral neuropore has not yet started at this point in development.

5th week (Option C): By this time, neural tube closure should have already been completed.

2nd week (Option D): This is too early in development as neurulation has not yet begun. The embryo is still in the process of gastrulation during this period.

questions.text: Which vitamin acts as a coenzyme required for Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Niacin

Explanation

  • Niacin, in the form of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP+), is required as a coenzyme for G6PD.
  • This enzyme catalyzes the first step of the pentose phosphate pathway, producing NADPH, which is essential for reductive biosynthesis and maintaining reduced glutathione in cells.

Niacin (Vitamin B3)

Chemical Structure
  • Niacin: Pyridine-3-carboxylic acid.
  • Niacinamide: Acid amide derivative.
  • Active tissue form: Niacinamide

Coenzyme Forms and Functions
  • NAD+: Generates 2.5 ATPs in oxidative phosphorylation.
  • NADPH: Used in reductive biosynthesis (e.g., fatty acid synthesis).
  • Provides ADP-ribose for protein modification (ADP-ribosylation).

Synthesis and Metabolism
  • 60 mg of tryptophan = 1 mg niacin (requires pyridoxal phosphate-dependent kynureninase).
  • Niacin attaches to ribose phosphate, forming a mononucleotide, then combines with AMP to form dinucleotides.

Deficiency Causes
  • Dietary Deficiency: Staple diets like maize (bound niacin) or sorghum (leucine inhibits niacin conversion).
  • Enzyme Defects: Pyridoxal deficiency inhibits kynureninase activity.
  • Drugs: Isoniazid inhibits pyridoxal phosphate formation.
  • Congenital Disorders: Hartnup disease (impaired tryptophan absorption and increased urinary excretion).
  • Carcinoid Syndrome: Excess tryptophan used for serotonin synthesis.

Clinical Condition
  • Pellagra: Niacin or tryptophan deficiency causing "rough skin".
  • Symptoms (3 Ds): Dermatitis (Casal’s necklace), Diarrhea (may involve blood/mucus), Dementia (irritability, poor memory, delirium).

Sources
  • Richest: Dried yeast, rice
  • , liver, peanuts, cereals, legumes, meat, fish.
  • 50% requirement met by tryptophan conversion.

RDA
  • Adults: 20 mg/day; Additional 5 mg during lactation.

Therapeutic Uses
  • Lowers serum cholesterol and Lp(a) by reducing free fatty acid flux from adipose tissue.

Toxicity
  • Excess (>50 mg/day): Vasodilation, itching, liver damage.

Riboflavin (Option A): Riboflavin is a precursor for flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and flavin mononucleotide (FMN), which are coenzymes in redox reactions. However, these are not directly involved with G6PD activity.

Thiamine (Option B): Thiamine, as thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), is a coenzyme for enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism, such as pyruvate dehydrogenase and transketolase, but not for G6PD.

Biotin (Option D): Biotin serves as a coenzyme for carboxylase enzymes involved in carboxylation reactions, such as pyruvate carboxylase, but not for G6PD.

questions.text: Which part of renal tubules reabsorbs maximum water in the presence of ADH?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Collecting duct

Explanation:

  • Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH) primarily acts on the collecting ducts of the kidneys. In the presence of ADH, the collecting ducts become more permeable to water by increasing the expression of aquaporin-2 channels on the tubular cells.
  • This allows more water to be reabsorbed from the filtrate back into the bloodstream, helping to concentrate urine and conserve water in the body.

Tonicity in Nephron segments with relation to plasma:

Nephron Segment

Tonicity relative to Plasma

Filtration (Glomerulus)

Isotonic (Same as plasma osmolality)

Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT)

Isotonic

  • Absorption of solute is proportional to the reabsorption of water.

Thin Descending Limb

Hypertonic (Water reabsorption, no solute reabsorption)

  • Isotonic - - - - -> Hypertonic

Thick Ascending Limb

 

Isotonic (Solute reabsorption, no water reabsorption)

  • Hypertonic - - - - - > Isotonic

Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT)

Hypotonic

Collecting Duct (CD)

It depends upon the presence of ADH in the blood
  • With ADH, more reabsorption of water and Hypertonic.
  • Without ADH, water reabsorption is nil, which is more hypotonic.

Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT) (Options A): does reabsorb a large amount of water, but this process is independent of ADH.

Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT) (Option B): reabsorbs a smaller portion of water, but the major site of ADH action is the collecting duct.

Loop of Henle(Option B): The ascending limb of the Loop of Henle is impermeable to water, while the descending limb reabsorbs water passively, but this is not directly influenced by ADH.

questions.text: What is the type of hernia in which the internal organ forms a portion of the wall of the hernia sac?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sliding hernia

Explanation:

  • A sliding hernia occurs when a part of an internal organ, such as the colon or bladder, forms part of the wall of the hernia sac.

Sliding hernia (Hernia-En-Glissade):

  • It occurs when a portion of the peritoneum that normally lines the abdominal cavity slides through the hernia defect, bringing a partially retroperitoneal organ.
  • More common in males, particularly the elderly (Option A ruled out) and frequently occurs on the left side, where the sigmoid colon is the most common content, not the appendix. (Option D ruled out)
  • The posterior wall of the hernia sac is formed by the viscera (commonly bowel), not the anterior wall. (Option B ruled out)
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Patients typically present with a reducible swelling in the groin or lower abdomen that worsens on standing due to gravity.
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation and incomplete bowel emptying are common, indicating bowel involvement.
  • Managed surgically by repairing or closing the defect, but associated with a higher risk of bowel injury due to the involvement of the viscera in the hernia sac.

 

Incorrect Options:

Lumbar hernia (Option A) refers to hernias occurring in the lumbar region of the abdominal wall but does not involve an internal organ forming part of the wall of the sac.

Spigelian hernia (Option C) occurs through the Spigelian fascia, which is located on the lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle and does not involve an internal organ as part of the hernia sac wall.

Richter hernia (Option D) is a type of hernia in which only a portion of the bowel wall (usually the antimesenteric border) is incarcerated, but it does not form the wall of the hernia sac.

questions.text: What is the ANMOL program for auxiliary nurse midwives?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Tablet-based software

Explanation:

ANMOL (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife Online) is a digital application for tablets designed for Auxiliary Nurse Midwives (ANMs) in India to improve healthcare service delivery. It is a mobile/tablet-based application developed under the National Health Mission (NHM).

Features of ANMOL:

  • Digital Data Entry – Helps ANMs record and update data of beneficiaries online.
  • Real-time Tracking – Monitors maternal and child health, immunisation, and nutrition status.
  • Paperless Work – Reduces the burden of maintaining physical registers.
  • Decision Support – Provides alerts and reminders for due services.
  • Integration with RCH Portal – Syncs data with the Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) portal for centralised monitoring.

Benefits for ANMs:

  • Increases efficiency in service delivery.
  • Helps track pregnant women and newborns for timely interventions.
  • Ensures accurate and up-to-date health records.
  • ANMOL enhances maternal and child healthcare services by making data accessible, reliable, and easy to use for frontline health workers.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D are incorrect

questions.text: Shield ulcer is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Atopic keratoconjunctivitis

Explanation:

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis or Spring catarrh

It is a recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis that tends to occur with the onset of warm weather. It primarily affects young children and adolescents, particularly boys.

Course

The condition typically starts in childhood and may resolve on its own over 5–10 years.

Symptoms

Burning, Itching, Photophobia (sensitivity to light), and lacrimation (excessive tearing).

Signs
  • Palpebral Form: Hypertrophied palpebral conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance; bluish-white color; dense fibrous tissue with thickened epithelium.
  • Limbal or Bulbar Form: Opacification at the limbus, gelatinous thickening, and Horner–Trantas dots
  • Pseudogerontoxon/cupid’s bow (which resembles arcus senilis) is a grayish-white ring at the limbus seen in severe limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).
  • Shield ulcers are a significant complication of VKC, particularly in severe cases. These microerosions typically form on the upper third of the cornea.
  • Mixed form: Exhibits characteristics of both the tarsal (palpebral) and limbal subtypes, typically presenting in only one eye.

Maxwell Lyon's sign is a pseudomembrane formed due to excessive mucus deposition on the papilla resulting in cobblestone papillae.

Histology

In the palpebral form, hypertrophied papillae are observed, rich in eosinophils and other inflammatory cells.

Treatment
  • Topical therapy:
    • Antihistamines - Levocabastine & emedastine
    • Mast cell stabilizers - Sodium cromoglicate
    • Mild steroids - Fluorometholone and loteprednol etabonate,
    • Acetylcysteine can control excess mucus.
  • Local therapy: Subtarsal steroid injections and cryotherapy for severe cases.
  • Surgical treatment: Excision of giant papillae and treatment of shield ulcers with debridement and amniotic membrane or bandage contact lens.
  • Cold compresses and tinted glasses for comfort.
  • Avoid eye rubbing

Phlyctenular conjunctivitis (Option B):

  • Allergy caused by endogenous antigens → Staph. aureus and TB infection
  • It presents with watering and itching in the eyes
  • O/E: nodule of phlycten near the limbus and conjunctival congestion

Atopic keratoconjunctivitis (Option C):

  • Common in temperate regions and winters
  • Dennie-morgan folds present
  • Presence of Madarosis and Hertoghe’s sign

Autoimmune Conditions (Option D):

  • Not typically associated with Shield Ulcer: Various autoimmune diseases can affect the eyes, such as rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and Sjögren's syndrome, leading to conditions like dry eye, scleritis, and uveitis. However, shield ulcers are not commonly seen as a direct manifestation of these autoimmune conditions.

questions.text: Optic nerve glioma is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) NF-1

Explanation:Optic nerve gliomas usually present with proptosis, visual loss, and optic nerve swelling, but not typically with leukocoria or an intraocular mass with calcification. Various conditions other than retinoblastoma, which present as leukocoria are collectively called pseudoglioma.

Differential diagnosis of Retinoblastoma

Leukocoria
  • Congenital cataract
  • Inflammatory deposits in vitreous following a plastic cyclitis or choroiditis,
  • Coloboma of the choroid,
  • Retinopathy of prematurity
  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous
  • Toxocara endophthalmitis
  • Exudative retinopathy of Coats

Endophytic retinoblastoma
  • Tuberous sclerosis
  • Neurofibromatosis-1 (Option A)
  • Astrocytoma

Exophytic Retinoblastoma
  • Exudative retinopathy of Coats

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Optic nerve glioma is not associated with these conditions.

questions.text: Identify the condition in a neonate with the swelling of the head shown in the image below at a few weeks of life?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cephalhematoma

Explanation:

  • The clinical picture resembles a cephalhematoma, which is a subperiosteal hemorrhage occurring in neonates.
  • This condition is characterized by a well-circumscribed swelling that develops within the first few hours after birth. The hemorrhage is limited by the suture lines due to the tight adherence of the periosteum at these locations. [1] [2]

 

Feature

Caput succedaneum (Option A)

Cephalhematoma

(Option B)

Subgaleal hemorrhage (Option C)

Location

At point of contact; can extend across sutures

Usually over parietal bones; does not cross sutures

Beneath epicranial aponeurosis; may extend to orbits, nape of neck

Characteristic findings

Vaguely demarcated; pitting edema that shifts with gravity

Distinct margins; initially firm, more fluctuant after 48 h

Firm to fluctuant; ill-defined borders; may have crepitus or fluid waves

Timing

Maximal size and firmness at birth; resolves in 48-72 h

Increases after birth for 12-24 h; resolution over 2-3 wk

Progressive after birth; resolution over 2-3 wk

Volume of blood

Minimal

Rarely severe

May be massive, especially if there is an associated coagulopathy

Association

-

Linear skull fracture (5-25%); hyperbilirubinemia

-

 

 

Encephalocele (Option D): This is a congenital condition where meninges and/or brain tissue protrude through a defect in the skull, typically occurring in the midline. It's present at birth and doesn't develop in the postnatal period.

questions.text: Ideal thickness of lead aprons to be worn by workers working in radiology department?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 0.5mm

Explanation:

  • Lead aprons are used to protect from the radiation received during an invetigation
  • The lead apron protects us from the scattered radiation that comes from the patient
  • The minimum thickness of the lead apron recommended is 0.25 mm according to the Indian guidelines.
  • 0.5 mm according to international guidelines
  • In India, most commonly 0.5 mm thickness is preferred.

Key Points on Lead Aprons and Radiation Protection

  1. Purpose of Lead Aprons:
    • Used to protect healthcare workers and others from scattered radiation during medical investigations.
    • Scatter radiation primarily arises from the patient and is caused by the Compton effect.
  2. Materials Used:
    • Traditional lead aprons are heavy.
    • Lightweight, lead-free aprons are now made using antimony and bismuth.
  3. Material Properties:
    • Radiation shielding materials must have a high atomic weight to block high-energy radiation effectively.
  4. Thickness Guidelines:
    • Indian Guidelines: Minimum lead thickness is 0.25 mm, with 0.5 mm preferred for better protection.
    • International Guidelines: Recommend 0.5 mm lead thickness.
  5. Additional Protective Equipment:
    • Lead gloves: Protect hands during procedures like fluoroscopy.
    • Thyroid shields: Protect the thyroid gland, especially during radiation exposure.
  6. Radiation-Induced Thyroid Cancer:
    • Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid cancer associated with radiation exposure.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with a history of GTCS came with an episode of convulsions for more than 45 minutes. What will be the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam

Explanation:

  • Status epilepticus (SE) is defined as continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness lasting more than 30 minutes.

They are generally of 2 types:

  • Generalized convulsive status epilepticus (GCSE)
    • GCSE is an emergency and must be treated immediately (e.g., persistent, generalized electrographic seizures, coma, and tonic-clonic movements).
  • Nonconvulsive status epilepticus (NCSE)
    • E.g., persistent absence seizures or focal seizures with confusion or partially impaired consciousness, and minimal motor abnormalities.

In the case of impending and early SE, the standard protocol involves administering IV lorazepam 0.1 mg/kg followed by levetiracetam 20-30 mg/kg.

For established and early refractory SE, the treatment progresses to Propofol 2 mg/kg IV followed by 2-10 mg/kg/hr with the addition of anticonvulsants like levetiracetam.

Management of Status Epilepticus:

Valproate followed by gabapentin (Option B): While valproate can be used in the treatment of GTCS, this combination is not the standard first-line treatment for status epilepticus. Gabapentin is typically used for chronic seizure management rather than acute status epilepticus.

Carbamazepine followed by lorazepam (Option C): Carbamazepine is primarily used in the treatment of partial or focal seizures and is not appropriate for acute status epilepticus. Additionally, benzodiazepines should be administered first in status epilepticus, not after other anticonvulsants.

Levetiracetam followed by valproate (Option D): This sequence is incorrect as benzodiazepines (lorazepam) should be the first-line treatment in early status epilepticus.

questions.text: Which nerve is most commonly injured during indirect inguinal hernia surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ilioinguinal nerve

Explanation:

The most commonly injured nerve during open inguinal hernia surgery is the ilioinguinal nerve, often leading to chronic pain as a complication.

  • The most common nerve injured in:
    • Open repair: Ilio-inguinal > Iliohypogastric > Genital branch of Genitofemoral nerve.
    • Laparoscopy: Lateral Cutaneous nerve of thigh > Genito-femoral nerve.
  • Landmarks in Laparoscopic Surgery:
    • Triangle of Doom: Injury to Iliac vessels
    • Triangle of Pain: Injury to Nerves causing postoperative pain

Complications of Surgery:

  • Immediate Complications:
    • Bleeding/Hematoma: From subcutaneous or inferior epigastric vessels.
    • Urinary Retention: May require catheterization.
    • Femoral Nerve Blockade
  • Early Postoperative Issues (within the first week):
    • Pain, Bruising, Swelling: Common.
    • Seroma Formation: Often resolves spontaneously; may need aspiration.
    • Wound Infection: Less frequent; routine antibiotics not recommended.
    • Testicular Infarction: Damage to the testicular artery during dissection or repair.
  • Long-term Concerns:
    • Chronic Pain:
      • Nerve Injury: Damage to nerves such as the ilioinguinal or iliohypogastric nerves during surgery.
      • Nerve Irritation: Chronic irritation by suture material or mesh.
      • Psychological Factors
    • Hernia Recurrence: Inadequate repair or weakness in the abdominal wall; mesh-related issues may also contribute.

questions.text: A diabetic patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of fatigue and frequent urination. On examination vitals are stable and an HbA1c is done. What is the cut-off percentage used for determining controlled diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 7.0

Explanation:

  • According to the American College of Physicians, the target HbA1c for determining controlled diabetes is <7.0% for adults with diabetes. This value represents optimal glycemic control, though it may be adjusted to <8.0% in elderly frail patients.

Glycated Hemoglobin (HbA1c) effectively assesses overall glycemic control and is suitable for diagnosing diabetes in asymptomatic individuals.

HbA1c prediction in undiagnosed individuals:

  • < 5.7% : Normal
  • 5.7% - 6.5% : Pre-diabetic
  • > 6.5% : Diabetic

For patients with existing diabetes, HbA1c is used to evaluate the degree of effective control on diabetes.

The cutoffs recommended by ACP for monitoring effective control include:

  • HbA1c < 7.0%
  • Preprandial capillary plasma glucose between 80-130 mg/dL
  • Postprandial capillary plasma glucose <180 mg/dL.

6.0 (Option A), 6.5 (Option B) & 7.5 (Option D) are incorrect values according to ACP recommendation.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant presents with immediate crying after breastfeeding, accompanied by diarrhea and vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Galactosemia

Explanation

  • Galactosemia is caused by a deficiency in galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). It leads to an inability to metabolize galactose from breast milk or formula, resulting in vomiting, diarrhea, failure to thrive, and potential liver damage.
  • Immediate symptoms after breastfeeding strongly suggest this condition.

Galactosemia

Enzyme Deficiency
  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT) - Classical type
  • Galactokinase- benign disease with only oil drop cataract.
  • Epimerase- SNHL + symptoms of classical type

(Low galactose-based diet can be given which is contraindicated in the classical type)

Pathophysiology
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate (toxic causing jaundice, and liver damage)
  • Inability to metabolize galactose from milk
  • Damage to liver, kidney, and brain

Clinical Features
  • Hepatic: Jaundice, hepatomegaly
  • GI: Vomiting, diarrhea, failure to thrive
  • CNS: Seizures, intellectual disability
  • Eyes: Oil drop cataracts
  • Increased risk of E. coli sepsis

Diagnosis
  • Reducing substance in urine (positive)( Positive Benedict test but negative glucose oxidase test)
  • Direct enzyme (GALT) assay
  • Genetic testing (Perinatal diagnosis is possible)

Management
  • Lactose-free diet
  • Breast Milk contraindicated
  • Soy-based or elemental formulas
  • Calcium supplementation

Lactose Intolerance (Option A): While lactose intolerance involves difficulty digesting lactose in breast milk, it typically presents later in childhood or adulthood.

Duodenal Atresia (Option B): Duodenal atresia presents with bilious vomiting shortly after birth and is associated with the "double bubble" sign on imaging. It does not specifically correlate with crying or diarrhea after breastfeeding.


Pyloric Stenosis (Option D): Pyloric stenosis presents with projectile non-bilious vomiting, typically around 2-6 weeks of age, but it is not associated with diarrhea or crying immediately after breastfeeding.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs is associated with visual disturbances?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ethambutol

Explanation:

Ethambutol is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that is associated with visual disturbances, which particularly causes retrobulbar neuritis, decreased visual acuity and colour blindness.

Ethambutol

MOA

Inhibits arabinosyl transferases involved in arabinogalactan synthesis, thereby interfering with mycolic acid synthesis in cell wall

Mechanism of resistance

Mutation of embAB genes, which encodes the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, reducing its affinity for ethambutol

Uses

In the treatment of

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)
  • Mycobacterium kansasii

Side effects
  • Painless loss of vision
    • Field defects due to retrobulbar neuritis
    • Loss of visual acuity
    • Red-green colour blindness
  • Nausea, rashes, fever

Rifampicin (Option A) has side effects that include hepatotoxicity, flu-like symptoms, and red-orange discoloration of urine. It is not associated with visual disturbances.

Streptomycin (Option B) is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used in multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis treatment. It can cause ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, but it is not typically associated with visual disturbances.


Pyrazinamide (Option C) is used as part of the combination therapy for tuberculosis. It is known to cause side effects like hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia, but visual disturbances are not a common side effect of this drug.

questions.text: Which of the following oxygen-sensitive channels is present in peripheral chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Potassium (K+)

Explanation:

  • The ion primarily involved in the function of O₂-sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors is Potassium (K⁺).
  • These channels play a crucial role in oxygen sensing within the carotid bodies, which are the main chemoreceptor sites for detecting changes in blood oxygen levels.
  • When oxygen levels drop, the O₂-sensitive potassium channels close, leading to cell depolarization and the subsequent release of neurotransmitters that signal the brain to increase respiration and blood pressure to maintain oxygen homeostasis​

Sodium (Na⁺) (Option B): is not directly involved in the O2-sensitive channels. They play a different role in other cellular processes but are not the key ions for oxygen sensitivity in peripheral chemoreceptors.

Calcium (Ca++) (Option C): is not directly involved in the O2-sensitive channels.

Chloride (Cl⁻) (Option D): does not play a direct role in the functioning of O2-sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors.

questions.text: An infant presents to the Pediatrics OPD with a distended abdomen and jaundice. The mother reports that the baby has shown an increased appetite in recent months. During the clinical examination, the physician notes hepatomegaly. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyl Transferase

Explanation:

Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyl Transferase deficiency causes classic galactosemia, a severe metabolic disorder characterized by hepatomegaly, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia due to the accumulation of toxic metabolites like galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol.

Galactosemia

Enzyme Deficiency
  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT) - Classical type
  • Galactokinase- benign disease with only oil drop cataract.
  • Epimerase- SNHL + symptoms of classical type

(Low galactose-based diet can be given which is contraindicated in the classical type)

Pathophysiology
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate (toxic causing jaundice, and liver damage)
  • Inability to metabolize galactose from milk
  • Damage to liver, kidney, and brain

Clinical Features
  • Hepatic: Jaundice, hepatomegaly
  • GI: Vomiting, diarrhea, failure to thrive
  • CNS: Seizures, intellectual disability
  • Eyes: Oil drop cataracts
  • Increased risk of E. coli sepsis

Diagnosis
  • Reducing substance in urine (positive)( Positive Benedict test but negative glucose oxidase test)
  • Direct enzyme (GALT) assay
  • Genetic testing (Perinatal diagnosis is possible)

Management
  • Lactose-free diet
  • Breast Milk contraindicated
  • Soy-based or elemental formulas
  • Calcium supplementation

Glycogen synthase (Option A): A deficiency in glycogen synthase leads to Glycogen Storage Disease Type 0, characterized by fasting hypoglycemia but without hepatomegaly or jaundice.

Glycogen Phosphorylase (Option B): Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (as seen in McArdle disease) affects muscle glycogen breakdown, leading to exercise intolerance and muscle cramps. It does not cause hepatomegaly or jaundice.


Glucose-6-Phosphatase (Option C): Deficiency of it causes glycogen storage disease type I (Von Gierke disease), which presents with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, and lactic acidosis.

questions.text: An audiogram of a 30-year-old female is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Otosclerosis

  • There is a dip in the bone conduction curve at 2000Hz in the graph of a 30-year-old female shown above which is called as Carhatz notch.
  • Carhatz notch is seen in otosclerosis.
  • The air conduction seen in the graph is also affected

 

Incorrect Options:

Meniers disease (Option B):

  • Upsloping graph seen in Meniere's disease
  • Both AC and BC are affected because of SNHL but the loss is seen at lower frequencies and at higher frequency the hearing sensitivity is almost normal.
  • Low frequency type of hearing loss is a Characteristic of Meniere's disease.

 

Noise-induced hearing loss (Option C):

  • The BC and AC curve of the ears is in the abnormal range, which means there is sensorineural hearing loss.
  • At 4000 Hz there is a dip in both AC and BC, this is called the boiler's notch which is specific in noise-induced hearing loss.

 

Presbycusis (Option D):

  • Presbyacusis is an age related SNHL.
  • AC and BC are abnormal, with no A-B gap.
  • This is a typical scene in sensorineural hearing loss
  • A down-sloping graph is very specific in presbycusis

questions.text: An adult male presents to the outpatient department with a painful scrotal swelling accompanied by fever. The swelling is associated with the tunica vaginalis and is characterized by fluid accumulation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hydrocele

Explanation: A hydrocele is characterized by the buildup of fluid within the tunica vaginalis, the protective membrane surrounding the testis. This condition can cause scrotal swelling, which may be painful or uncomfortable and occasionally accompanied by fever.

Hydrocele:

  • Collection of fluid between the two layers of the tunica vaginalis of the testis

Aetiology
  • Defective absorption of fluid by tunica vaginalis due to endothelial wall damage by low-grade infection
  • Excessive production of fluid (secondary hydrocele)
  • Interference with drainage of fluid by lymphatic vessels of the cord
  • Communication with the peritoneal cavity

Primary Vaginal Hydrocele
  • Common in middle-aged men, prevalent in tropical countries
  • Testis is usually large and non-palpable
  • Fluctuant
  • Can get above the swelling
  • Initially transilluminant, but becomes non-transilluminant if long-standing

Infantile Hydrocele
  • Tunica and processus vaginalis distended up to the internal ring
  • No connection with the peritoneal cavity

Congenital Hydrocele
  • Processus vaginalis communicates with the peritoneal cavity
  • Fluid disappears when lying down and recollects when standing

Encysted Hydrocele of the Cord
  • Fluid collection in a portion of the patent funicular process of tunica vaginalis
  • Fluctuant and transilluminant
  • Located in the inguinal/inguinoscrotal/scrotal part

Secondary Vaginal Hydrocele
  • Causes: Infection (filariasis, tuberculosis), injury (trauma, post herniorrhaphy), tumor (malignancy)
  • Usually small, lax, and testis is palpable except in cases of filariasis where it can be very large

Surgical Procedure
  • Lord's plication - small, thin hydrocele with clear fluid
  • Jaboulay's operation - partial sac removal and eversion

Incorrect Options:

Varicocele (Option A) involves dilation of the pampiniform plexus of veins and typically presents as a soft, irregular mass that may feel like a "bag of worms." It is usually asymptomatic, though it can sometimes cause pain or infertility.

Cystocele (Option C) refers to the prolapse of the bladder into the vaginal canal and is not related to scrotal swelling.

Torsion testis (Option D) is a surgical emergency caused by twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to compromised blood flow to the testis. It typically presents with acute, severe pain and swelling but does not usually involve fluid accumulation in the tunica vaginalis. The swelling is often more tender and associated with an absence of the cremasteric reflex.

questions.text: A patient with acute rheumatic fever was presented in the OPD. Examination shows- gram-positive cocci in chains. The etiological agent is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Streptococcus pyogenes

Explanation: Streptococcus pyogenes, also known as Group A Streptococcus (GAS), is the etiological agent of acute rheumatic fever. This bacterium is a gram-positive cocci that typically forms chains and is responsible for a variety of infections, including pharyngitis (strep throat), which can lead to rheumatic fever as a complication, especially in children. Rheumatic fever is a post-infectious inflammatory disease that can affect the heart, joints, skin, and nervous system.

questions.text: Radioisotope used in PET-CT scan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 18F-FDG

Explanation:

  • 18F-FDG (Fluorodeoxyglucose) is the most commonly used radiotracer in PET-CT scans.
  • It is a glucose analog labeled with the radioactive isotope Fluorine-18.
  • It accumulates in tissues with high glucose metabolism, such as cancer cells, inflammation, or infection, making it highly useful for diagnosing and staging cancers, monitoring treatment response, and detecting recurrent disease.

Fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron-emission tomography (PET-FDG)

  • Uptake of 18F-FDG (Analogue of endogenous glucose) in large quantities by cancer cells as compared to normal cells

Application:

  • Quantification of tumor metabolic activity
  • Diagnosis (lung cancer) and Staging of cancer
  • Assessing distant metastasis
    • More sensitive in primary lung and oesophageal cancer metastatic disease
  • Assessment of response to treatment
    • A decrease in FDG uptake after chemotherapy indicates that the tumor is responding to treatment
  • Routine surveillance following treatment- not commonly preferred.

Not useful in the following situations:

  • High Glycolytic Metabolism tissues: Central nervous system tumors.
  • Inflammation vs. Cancer: Both conditions exhibit increased glucose metabolism.
  • Movement disorders
  • Coronary blood flow

Warburg Effect

  • Cancer cells prefer glycolysis over oxidative phosphorylation, even in the presence of oxygen.
  • This leads to increased glucose uptake and lactate production, common in many cancers.
  • 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (18F-FDG), a glucose analog used in PET imaging, helps study this effect.

Mechanisms of 18F-FDG Accumulation

Mechanism

Description

Aerobic Glycolysis

Cancer cells rely heavily on glycolysis, increasing glucose and 18F-FDG uptake, even with oxygen.

Transport & Trapping

GLUT-1 transporters mediate glucose entry. 18F-FDG is phosphorylated and trapped inside cells.

Tumor Heterogeneity

Differences in tumor subtype, size, and microvasculature affect 18F-FDG uptake.

Clinical Implications of 18F-FDG

Implication

Details

Prognostic Indicator

Higher 18F-FDG uptake correlates with worse prognosis (e.g., shorter DFS in invasive ductal carcinoma).

Reverse Warburg Effect

Cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) increase glycolysis in tumor cells via metabolic coupling.

Treatment Monitoring

PET imaging tracks changes in 18F-FDG uptake, reflecting therapy responses targeting glycolysis or mitochondria.

Iodine (Option B): Radioactive iodine (e.g., I-131 or I-123) is mainly used in thyroid imaging and treatment of thyroid disorders

Radium (Option C): Radium-223 is used in the treatment of bone metastases (e.g., in prostate cancer)

Cesium-131 (Option D): Cesium-131 is used in brachytherapy for localized radiation delivery (e.g., in prostate cancer)

questions.text: What are the characteristic laboratory findings in primary hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Elevated TSH, low T4 levels

Explanation:

  • The characteristic laboratory findings in primary hypothyroidism are elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels and low free thyroxine (T4) levels.
  • This is because, in primary hypothyroidism, the thyroid gland fails to produce sufficient thyroid hormones, leading to decreased feedback inhibition of the pituitary gland, which in turn increases TSH production to try to stimulate the thyroid gland.

Primary vs Secondary Hypothyroidism:

Feature

Primary Hypothyroidism

Secondary Hypothyroidism

Definition

Thyroid gland dysfunction leads to inadequate thyroid hormone production

Pituitary dysfunction leads to insufficient TSH secretion

Causes
  • Autoimmune (Hashimoto's thyroiditis)
  • Iatrogenic (e.g., post-thyroidectomy, radiation)
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Medications (e.g., amiodarone, lithium)
  • Infiltrative diseases (e.g., sarcoidosis)
  • Food goitrogen → Cabbage, cassava.
  • Pituitary tumors
  • Pituitary surgery or radiation
  • Sheehan’s syndrome
  • Trauma
  • Genetic pituitary hormone deficiencies
  • Non-obstetric cause of pituitary damage called Simmonds's disease (AVM, tumor, HTN)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hemochromatosis

Lab

TSH - ↑;

Free T3/T4 - ↓

TSH - Normal or ↓;

Free T3/T4 - ↓ (Option D)

Clinical Features
  • Fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance
  • Dry skin, hair loss
  • Bradycardia, constipation
  • Myxedema (puffy face, non-pitting edema)
  • Similar to primary hypothyroidism
  • Other pituitary hormone deficiencies (e.g., low cortisol, low LH/FSH)

Treatment

Levothyroxine (T4) replacement with dosage based on TSH levels

Levothyroxine (T4) replacement, but monitored by free T4 levels (since TSH is unreliable)

Elevated TSH, low T3 levels (Option B): While low T3 levels can occur in primary hypothyroidism, T4 levels are more commonly measured and are more indicative of thyroid function. Low T3 alone is not specific enough to diagnose primary hypothyroidism without considering T4 levels​

Elevated TSH, elevated T4 levels (Option C): This combination is not characteristic of primary hypothyroidism. Elevated TSH with elevated T4 levels might indicate resistance to thyroid hormone or a rare TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma, but not primary hypothyroidism​

questions.text: A patient experienced a fall onto an outstretched hand, and an X-ray revealed a fracture of the first metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint with accompanying subluxation. Define this type of fracture.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Bennett’s fracture

Explanation:

  • Bennett’s fracture is an oblique intra-articular fracture dislocation at the base of the first metacarpal bone (the thumb).

Bennett fracture:

  • Oblique intra-articular fracture (2 part) of the base of the first metacarpal with subluxation of the metacarpal.
  • It is caused by a longitudinal force applied to the thumb.
  • Treatment:
    • Closed reduction and percutaneous K-wire fixation
    • Open reduction and internal fixation

 

  • Scaphoid (Options B) occurs from a fall on a dorsiflexed hand, typically affecting the waist of the scaphoid, and is characterised by pain and tenderness in the anatomical snuff box (the scaphoid fossa).
  • Reverse Colle’s fracture (Options C) involves a fracture at the distal end of the radius.
  • Colle’s fracture (Options D) is due to fracture of radius and presents with Dinner-fork deformity

questions.text: Cervarix vaccine is effective against which of the following Human papillomavirus serotypes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HPV 16 and 18

Explanation:

  • Cervarix is a bivalent HPV vaccine specifically targeting high-risk oncogenic serotypes 16 and 18.

 

HPV 6 and 11 (Option B): These are low-risk types primarily causing genital warts, targeted by Gardasil but not Cervarix.

HPV 6 and 16 (Option C): This combination includes one low-risk (6) and one high-risk (16) type. Cervarix only targets high-risk types 16 and 18.

HPV 11 and 18 (Option D): This combination includes one low-risk (11) and one high-risk (18) type. Cervarix specifically targets only high-risk types 16 and 18.

questions.text: Arrange the order of the Disaster management cycle
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Impact-response-rehabilitation-mitigation

Disaster management cycle:

The three fundamental aspects of disaster management:

  1. Disaster impact: Involves disaster response and relief.
  2. Disaster preparedness: It is the proper equipment of the country to manage disasters.
  3. Disaster mitigation: Preventing the hazard from becoming a disaster.

questions.text: Identify the hemorrhage shown in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Subdural hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • A crescent-shaped hemorrhage on imaging, particularly on CT or MRI, is characteristic of a subdural hemorrhage (SDH).

Feature

Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH) (Option A)

Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH)

Type of Hemorrhage

Arterial Hemorrhage

Venous Hemorrhage

Shape

Biconvex or lentiform

 

Crescent or sickle-shaped

 

Location

Limited by sutures; can cross the midline

Follows the brain surface; crosses sutures, does not cross midline

Cause

Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (MMA)

Rupture of cortical bridging veins

Onset of Symptoms

Often presents with a lucid interval

Symptoms may develop gradually, often without a lucid interval

Force Required

Requires more force; associated with adjacent bony rupture

Can occur with trivial trauma

Midline Crossing

Can cross the midline

Does not cross the midline

Lucid Interval

Yes; patient appears normal before deterioration

No; deterioration may be more gradual

Clinical Signs

Symptoms may include headache, loss of consciousness, and focal neurological deficits

Symptoms may include headache, confusion, and potential focal deficits

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) (Option C): SAH presents with bleeding in the subarachnoid space and shows diffuse blood in the sulci and cisterns rather than a localized collection.

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage (Option B): On NCCT,appears as a hyperdense lesion. The hemorrhage can typically be localized in regions such as the basal ganglia, particularly in the putamen and the internal capsule, which are critical for motor control and other functions.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to show the following finding on USG?

Correct Answer: A) Fibroadenoma

Explanation:

  • The ultrasound features—round/ovoid hypoechoic mass, parallel orientation (wider than tall)—are classic findings associated with a fibroadenoma, which is a benign breast lesion.
